entry.title: 科技英语2-introduction
entry.content:
1.快速阅读文献/抓住文章重心

  1. READ THE TITLE——and try to predict the type of information you expect to see
  2. LOOK AT THE NAME OF THE AUTHOR——What you know about the writer will help you predict and evaluate the content
  3. CHECK THE DATE——and use it to help you assess the content
  4. READ THE ABSTRACT——to find out what the researchers did and/or what they found
  5. LOOK QUICKLY AT THE FIRST PARAGRAPH——without trying to understand all the words
  6. LOOK QUICKLY AT THE FIRST SENTENCE OF EACH PARAGRAPH——without trying to understand all the words
  7. LOOK QUICKLY AT EACH FIGURE/TABLE AND READ ITS TITLE——to try and find out what type of visual data is included
  8. READ THE LAST PARAGRAPH——especially if it has a subtitle like ‘Summary’ or Conclusion

2. What are involved in an introduction?

  1. Introduce the topic of problem with which the research particle is concerned.
  2. Give a clear definition of the topic and of the related key terms.
  3. Provide the relevant background information/context of the topic.
  4. Review the previous related studies and point out their limitation if necessary. (Literature review)
  5. State the purpose/objective of the article.
  6. Introduce the theoretical perspectives the article might use.
  7. Justify the choice of the topic or give the reason for the research.
  8. Explain how the article will be organized (the outline of the article).

3. How to write an introduction

（1） Grammar

TENSE PAIRS

– Present Simple / Present Continuous

– Past Simple / Present Perfect

  1. The Present Simple tense is used in science writing to state accepted facts and truths.
  2. Present Continuous describes a temporary situation.
  3. Past Simple tense means that your findings are linked only to your own research, and you do not claim your deductions should be considered as accepted or established facts.
  4. Present Perfect indicates that the event in the past is relevant to the situation now.
  5. Tense changes are always meaningful, and they always signal a change in the function of the information - so don’t change tense randomly and make sure you remember to change tense when you should.

（2） Signalling language

① overlap

上下重复，保持联系

② pronoun/pro-form

（it,they,this method,these system）

③ semicolon/relative clause

分词（很容易用错）/关系从句

④ signalling sentence connector

  1. result
  2. contrast
  3. unexpectedness
  4. addition

（3）PARAGRAPHING

  1. Two common errors in paragraphing
    1. clusters of short or single-sentence paragraphs.
    2. paragraphs that are too long
  2. •How to make paragraphs?
    1. A paragraph in academic writing often starts with a topic sentence, which gives the main idea of the paragraph, and tells the reader what the paragraph is about.
    2. When the ‘topic’ or ‘idea’ moves too far away from the first sentence, the writer usually begins a new paragraph.
    3. When you are planning your paper, write down each idea/concept that you want to talk about, checking that they are in a logical order and then listing what you want to say about each, using bullet points. This will help you create paragraphs that have a logical and coherent structure.

（4）Build a model

  1. 原则

    1. Don’t expect to produce a perfect model now. You will modify your model during practice

  2. 样板例子

    1. In Sentence 1 the writer establishes the importance of this research

      1. Most research articles begin by indicating that the research field or topic is useful or significant.

      2. In the first one or two sentences, you need to establish the significance of the research. Find a list of useful vocabulary for this in Section 1.4.

      3. What tense should I write in here?

        Phrases like ‘much study in recent years or in the past five years’ are normally followed by the Present Perfect tense (‘much study in recent years has focused on…’). Other ways of establishing significance may use the Present Simple tense (‘There are substantial benefits to be gained from…’).

    2. In Sentence 2 the writer provides general background information

      1. State accepted or established facts. This ensures that the reader shares the same level of background information as the writer, and is therefore ready to read the article.

      2. What kind of facts should I start with?

        Start with the most general one, the one that many of your readers will already know. After that you can move on to more specific information. Always show your readers the general picture before you examine the details.

      3. If the article is to reach a wider audience you need to state background facts which seem obvious or well-known to you.

    3. In Sentence 3 the writer does the same as in Sentences 1 and 2， but in a more specific/detailed way.

      1. It’s still part of the background to general research in this area.

      2. A literature review comes later in the Introduction.

      3. Include adequate references because

        – plagiarism (failing to give others the appropriate credit for their work) is unprofessional;

        – referencing gives your reader the chance to find and read the study mentioned;

        – failing to provide a reference may indicate that you are not familiar with research in your area.

      4. Before you write a research paper, you collect a lot of references, quotations and ideas from journals and the Internet, many of which you will mention at some point in the paper. You may have this question - Which ones should be part of the background to the research (as in Sentence 3 above) and which ones should go in the literature review which comes later in the Introduction?

      5. If the findings are well-known and considered reliable enough to be presented as truths, you can present them in the Present Simple as part of the factual background to your paper (as in Sentence 3) with a research reference. The literature review, which describes recent and current research in your field, usually mentions authors by name, and the sentences are usually in the Simple Past or Present Perfect tense.

    4. In Sentence 4 the writer describes the general problem area or the current research focus of the field

      1. Describe the current focus of the field, a problem which many researchers in this field are interested in and which leads to the specific problem which will be addressed in this article.
      2. Remember to keep this general description of the problem area or current research focus brief. It’s not a specific description of what your research is trying to achieve.
      3. You may need a research reference when you describe the problem; however, if it is a well-known problem, then it is not necessary to provide a reference.

    5. In Sentence 5 the writer provides a transition between the general problem area and the literature review.

    6. In Sentence 6 the writer provides a brief overview of key research projects in this area.

      1. Arrange your references and studies so that the reader is able to process them in a logical way. (Watch video)https://www.icourse163.org/learn/NJUST-1001752040?tid=1450442469#/learn/content?type=detail&id=1214964214&cid=1219136286&replay=true
      2. Avoid confusion, for example if you are referring to more than one study in a sentence or if the citation reference only refers to part of your sentence.

    7. In Sentence 7 the writer describes a gap in the research.

      1. This is where you begin to introduce the purpose of your paper and the specific problem you will deal with.
      2. By describing a problem in the previous research or by indicating that there is a gap in the research. (signalling connectors however, although,…) In professional writing it is unusual to put it in the form of a question.
      3. Don’t be shy about pointing out the problems in previous research. The language used here is usually respectful and impersonal, and is therefore not considered offensive. Use polite vocabulary.

    8. In Sentences 8 the writer describes the paper itself

      1. You can describe it, say what its purpose or focus is, give its structure or a combination of these.

      2. You normally use the Present Simple tense to describe the work itself

        (This paper is organised as follows or This study focuses on) and the Past Simple tense to talk about the aim of the work (The aim of this project was…) It is also possible to state the aim in the Present Simple (The aim of this work is…).

    9. In Sentence 9 the writer gives details about the methodology reported in the paper.

    10. In Sentence 10 the writer announces the findings.

      1. Although you can give information about your methodology or findings in the Introduction, be careful not to go into too much detail at this point.
      2. In each case the information is joined to the previous sentence with a pro-form (On the basis of these criteria in Sentence 9 and This combination in Sentence 10).

4. Literature review

To demonstrate a clear understanding of the topic being investigated.

  1. what has been done on the topic (state-of-the-art)

  2. what major findings has been published and what controversial areas exist.

  3. give credit to what has been done in this field !

    – carefully search for references relevant to the topic before you write

    – focus on your topic when gathering sources

  4. point out where it is the lacking

  5. organize your review in a logical order; point out what is left to explore.

  6. Find the shoulders of the giant and climb on them.

entry.title: 学术英语3——方法和结果
entry.content:
1. The Structure of the Method Section

  1. Different titles of the method section
    1. Materials and Methods
    2. Theory and Methods
    3. Theoretical Framework and Methods
  2. The major elements in the method section
    1. Steps
    2. Materials
    3. Major elements involved:
      1. Overview of the experiment
      2. Population
      3. Location
      4. Restriction/Limiting conditions
      5. Sampling Techniques
      6. Materials
      7. Procedures
      8. Statistical Treatment
      9. Note: Not all the items are included in all disciplines
  3. The methodology section
    1. Methodology
    2. The rationales
    3. The fundamental reasons or principles of doing things
  4. Tips for avoiding plagiarism
    1. Acknowledging those authors/researchers to avoid plagiarism
      1. Being familiar with the theories and principles of designing and conducting experiments
      2. Referencing well

2. The Structure of the Results Section

  1. Major elements
    1. The statement showing where the results can be found
    2. The statement presenting the most important findings
    3. The statement commenting on the results
  2. The presentation of the results section
    1. Diagrams/Graphs
    2. Texts
  3. The order of the results
    1. Research questions
    2. Research methods
  4. The language focuses
    1. Sequential markers
    2. Graphic descriptions
    3. Comparison and contrast

3. Sequential Markers

  1. Importance of sequential markers

    1. Building up connections between ideas

    2. Ensuring that sentences and paragraphs flow together smoothly

      note；Pay attention to the procedure description and the writing of process paragraphs.

  2. Commonly used sequential markers

    1. To indicate a particular time frame or a shift from one time period
      to another
    2. words

4. Graphic Description

  1. Introduction of graphs
    1. The definition
      1. A graph is a diagram, usually a line or a curve, which shows how two or more and sets of numbers measurements are related
    2. The types
      1. Graphs usually include bar/column charts/graphs, pie charts and line graphs.
  2. Use of graphs in the results section
    1. Prepare the graphs as soon as all the data are analyzed and arrange them in the sequence that best presents your results in a logical way;
    2. Describe the graphs well because good descriptions can help the readers understand your research better.
  3. Description of Graphs
    1. Introduce the graphic information briefly and indicate the main trend. Normally it includes the place, time, content and purpose of the graph;
    2. Describe the relevant and most important or significant data and make some comparison if necessary;
    3. Summarize the data/trends
  4. Useful words, phrases or sentence patterns in different situations of graphic description.
    1. When Introducing the graphic information and making a general statement
    2. when referring to a graph
    3. when describing a graph
    4. when describing a curve or a trend
    5. when making a conclusion

5. Comparison and Contrast

  1. The definition and commonly used expressions
    1. The definition
      — Strictly speaking, comparison is to show the similarities
      while contrast is to show the differences
    2. Commonly used expressions
      1. comparison
        1. like
        2. too
        3. similar as
        4. similarly
        5. both
        6. likewise
        7. as well as
        8. also
        9. in the same way
        10. have in common
        11. the same as
      2. contrast
        1. although
        2. yet
        3. whereas,
        4. however
        5. but, while
        6. instead, unlike
        7. unless,
        8. be different from
        9. the reverse, differ
        10. contrary to, conversely
        11. even though, on the contrary
        12. on the other hand
  2. Two major ways of organization
    1. Block comparison or block contrast
      1. To examine one thing thoroughly and then examine the other
    2. Alternating comparison or alternating contrast
      1. To examine two things at the same time, discussing them point by point
  3. Tips for making comparison or contrast
    1. Not all the information has to be compared or contrasted
      with each other
    2. It is not necessary to lay equal emphasis on every change
    3. The comparison/contrast should be supported by
      concrete and relevant facts or data.

entry.title: 学术英语2-文献综述
entry.content:
1. Reviewing Literature

    1. Definition
      1. A literature review is a careful examination of a body of literature
        pointing toward the answer to your research question.
      2. context+background——current knowledge of the topic——a convincing thesis——research question
      3. An argument that present a case based on a comprehensive understanding of the current state of knowledge——a critical analysis of different opinions——Thesis Statement
    2. Types
      1. Research Interest—— Research Topic ——Research Thesis—— Literature Review
      2. 流程
        1. Select a Topic——specifies
        2. develop tools of argumentation——organize and form
        3. search the literature——explore and catalog
        4. survey the literature——document and discover
        5. critique the literature——advocate and defines
        6. write the thesis——Addresses and answers——1
    3. Tips
      1. Choose a review model.
      2. Collect, evaluate and select literature.
      3. Start writing now!
      4. Find connections and themes.

  2. Writing Literature Review

    1. What should we include in a literature review?
      1. What are the seminal works on my topic?
      2. What progress has been made since these seminal works?
      3. What are the most relevant recent works?
      4. What is the best order to mention these works?
      5. What are the achievements and limitations of these recent works?
      6. What gap do these limitations reveal?
      7. How does my work intend to fill this gap?
    2. How can we organize these ideas?
      1. Chronological － Trace the development of the topic over time
      2. Thematic － Address different aspects of the topic in subsections
      3. Methodological － Compare the results & conclusions from
        different approaches
      4. Theoretical － Discuss various theories, models, and definitions
        of key concepts.
    3. Are there any techniques that can be helpful?
      1. introduction to topic
      2. support from the literature
      3. mini summary
      4. introduction to next topic.
      5. Prepare the reader for the author’s hypothesis

  3. Avoiding Plagiarism

    1. Definition of Plagiarism
      1. the copying or paraphrasing of other people’s work or ideas into your own work without full acknowledgement http://www.ox.ac.uk/students/academic/goodpractice/about/
      2. the act of representing as one’s own original work the creative works of another, without appropriate acknowledgment of the author or source https://academichonesty.unimelb.edu.au/plagiarism.html
      3. the “wrongful appropriation” and “stealing and publication” of another author’s “language, thoughts, ideas, or expressions” and the representation of them as one’s own original work. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plagiarism
    2. Types of Plagiarism
    3. Avoidance of Plagiarism－Citing
      1. Use online tools to check for plagiarism
      2. Provide links you have referred to
      3. Write in your own words
    4. Citing Techniques
      1. Quoting: to put quotation marks around the words and identify the source.
        1. When language is particularly vivid or expressive.
        2. When exact wording is needed for technical accuracy.
        3. When the words of an important authority lend weight to an argument
      2. Paraphrasing: to put the information into your own words and identify the source
        1. Lexical transformation Syntactic transformation
        2. Use synonyms
        3. Change word forms
        4. Make necessary structural adjustments
        5. Change between the affirmative and the negative
        6. Change the voice from active to passive and vice versa
        7. Change clauses to phrases and vice versa
        8. Include reference to the original source
      3. Summarizing: to take the key ideas and paraphrase them and identify the source.
        1. definition
          1. Is to put in your own words a shortened version of written or spoken material, stating the main points and leaving out anything that is not essential
          2. Involves analyzing information, distinguishing important elements from unimportant elements and transforming large chunks of information into a few short cohesive sentences
        2. how
          1. Start by reading a short text and highlight the main points as you read
          2. Reread the text and make notes of the main points, leaving out examples, evidence, etc.
          3. Restate or repeat the ideas of the source in different words and phrases
          4. Do not add your own ideas, opinions or judgment of the arguments
          5. Make it shorter than the source

  4. Reporting Verbs

    1. Definition

      1. A reporting verb is a word which is used to talk about or
        report on other people’s work
      2. It is used to
        1. comment on someone’s work;
        2. agree or disagree with someone else’s study;
        3. evaluate someone’s ideas.
      3. Reporting verbs can indicate either
        1. the author’s personal viewpoint;
        2. the author’s viewpoint regarding other literature;
        3. your viewpoint regarding what the author say

    2. Function and strength of reporting verbs

      1. NEUTRAL

        1. definition: verbs used to say what the writer describes in factual terms, demonstrates, refers to, and discusses, and verbs used to explain his/her methodology.

        2. Example verbs

          describe, show, reveal, study, demonstrate, note,point out, indicate, report, observe, assume, take into consideration, examine, go on to say that, state, believe (unless this is a strong belief), mention, etc

      2. TENTATIVE

        1. definition: verbs used to say what the writer suggests or speculates on (without being absolutely certain).

        2. Example verbs

          suggest, speculate, intimate, hypothesize, moot, imply, propose, recommend, posit the view that, question the view that, postulate, etc.

      3. STRONG

        1. definition: verbs used to say what the writer makes strong arguments and claims for.

        2. Example verbs

          argue, claim, emphasize, contend, maintain, assert, theorize, support the view that, deny, negate, refute, reject, challenge, strongly believe that, counter the view/argument that, etc.

      4. warn

        1. Disagree
        2. Emphasize
        3. Examine

      5. reporting verbs

        1. say directly——state
        2. to examine the key points——discuss
        3. to highlight an important point ——emphasize
        4. give reasons for this view——argue
        5. give clear details about something——explain
        6. to say just briefly——note
        7. often used when others disagree——claim
        8. disagree with somebody or a theory——reject
        9. say indirectly that something is true ——suggest
        10. states but does not develop at length——point out
        11. suggests it is inaccurate ——question
        12. refer to briefly——mention
        13. the final point or summary —— conclude

  5. Tenses in Literature review

    1. Present simple
      1. The present simple or the present perfect are generally used to introduce the literature review.
      2. Use the present simple to discuss previously published laws, theories, definitions, proofs, lemmas etc. Such published work is generally considered to be established knowledge and the use of the present simple reflects this.
    2. Present perfect
      1. When we talk about completely finished actions, the present perfect
        cannot be used.
    3. Past simple
      1. The past simple cannot be used in any of these three cases
      2. You must use the past simple when:
        1. the year of publication is stated within the main sentence (i.e. not just
          in brackets)
        2. you mention specific pieces of research (e.g. you talk about initial
          approaches and methods that have subsequently probably been
          abandoned)
        3. you state the exact date when something was written or proved.

entry.title: 科技英语2
entry.content:
1. Grammar for EST (ENGLISH FOR science and technology)
    1. The main features of EST
      1. Objectivity, clarity, accuracy and formality. Different from literal works.
      2. Lexical feature (词汇特征)
        1. technical terms & semi-technical terms——技术术语
        2. borrowed/loan words
        3. coin words (新造词)
        4. abbreviation
    2. Grammatical feature (语法特征)—— tenses
      1. Tense changes are always meaningful, and they always signal a change in the function of the information — so don’t change tense randomly and make sure you remember to change tense when you should.
      2. Present Simple/ Present Continuous
        1. The Present Simple tense is used in science writing to state accepted facts and truths
        2. The gap/problem is normally in the Present Simple tense
        3. It is also possible to use the Present Simple tense to talk about your methodology, especially when you are referring to calculations or equations which can be found in the paper itself
        4. results——Present Simple可以
      3. Past Simple/Present Perfect
        1. When you are referring to your methodology（方法论）, or what you did during the research period, it is common to use the Past Simple tense
        2. resulits——Past Simple可以
      4. but be aware that the sentence may use two different tenses. Even if the first part of the sentence is in the Past Simple tense（ We found/It was found etc.） you can decide to put the finding/result itself or the implication of the result in the Present Simple tense if you believe it is strong enough to be considered as a fact or truth
    3. Passive voice (to achieve objectivity and formality)
      1. You can use we to refer to your research group or team, but do not use it to refer to people or humanity in general
      2. If you are referring to people in general, it’s better to use a construction with It (It is known/thought that…) rather than We** know/think that… It is also common to use the **passive instead of we, especially in the central ‘report’ section (was measured**, was added, etc**.)
      3. Use words like here and in this study to let your reader know when you are referring to your own work. You can also use a ‘dummy’ subject to take the place of I or we
    4. Stylistic feature (格式特征)
      1. impersonal
      2. formal mood
      3. standard language
      4. objective and accurate in statement
      5. strict in logic
  2. Prefixes and suffixes
    1. a-/an-; in-/ir-/il-/im-/ig-
    2. mal-; mis-; pseudo-
    3. anti-; contra-/contr-/counter-;
    4. with; op-/ob-
    5. hyper-; sub-; vice-
    6. tele-
    7. -tropic; -tropism
  3. semi-technical words
    1. High frequency (使用频率高)
    2. Interdisciplinary use (跨学科使用)
    3. Polysemy（一词多义）
    4. Low semantic load: work （低语义化）

entry.title: 微波毫米波工程设计0315
entry.content:
1. 移动通信最重要的指标是覆盖率，要提升覆盖率，又不想像纯粹基站那样消耗那么多电力，可以采用直放站或者4G/5G采用的比较多的中继RRU。
    1. 直放站——微波电路中更像就是一个放大器
      1. 链路仿真——增益和损失要建立一个概念和模型
      2. 缺点：
        1. 网络损耗没有考虑进去，放大器不仅放大信号还放大噪声，使得原基站的覆盖区域反而降低了，因为不能单纯考虑下行（基站-终端），也要考虑上行（终端-基站），不仅要正向考虑还要反向考虑，移动通信是双向通信。
        2. 直放站的功耗太高，没有时分/频分的概念，不知道什么时候开，什么时候关，耗电量很大。
    2. 4G/5G——直放站淘汰-中继relay/接力基站
      1. 优点
        1. 可以采用编码的方式抑制噪声
        2. 降低耗电量
        3. 时频可以不同
        4. 升级空间大——中继站可以升级成基站能力强
      2. 对于5G来说，育婴区域越大，越需要更多的中继处理——RRU-remote radio unit远端射频单元
        1. 对于现在的射频设计来说，数字电路尤其是高速数字电路的比重只会越来越大，边缘计算使得射频端要包含越来越多的数字电路，数字化是大势所趋。
        2. BBU(building baseband unit)和RRU构成enode B
        3. 5G一个很重要的指标是降低网络延时——扁平化设计/分布式设计/cell-free设计
          1. 分布式模型就是1个BBU对应1个RRU变成1个BBU对应多个小RRU
          2. 这样的变化能够明显降低信噪比，利用好MIMO技术降低规模和成本
  2. TDD/FDD RRU
    1. 架构
      1. CPRI(common public radio interface)-DIF-DPD-DAC-正交调制-PA-双工器/TR开关-天线
      2. 天线-双工器/TR开关-LNA-正交调制-ADC-DPD-DIF-CPRI
    2. 标准数字接口
      1. 波形/数字基带/IQ方式——各企业相同
      2. 信令控制——各企业不同
    3. 数据量急剧增长时，数字基带的容量要改变制式扩容
    4. ADCDAC的接口需要FPGA，此外还可以在ADC后部分解码来降低数据处理量
    5. TDD—收发切换开关 FDD—滤波器选择频率（TDD一直占据主流）
  3. 3.5GHz RRU RF基带单板
  4. AD9371集成式宽带RF收发器
    1. 直接解调难度很大
    2. 产品参数不仅要看优点更要看缺点，还要注意很多细节——限制情况
    3. 缺点
      1. 噪声系数很大
      2. 哪怕应用于pico-cell功率也不够
    4. 测试——入网的限制你要看每项具体的测试参数
      1. 每一项指标没可能讨价还价
      2. 有时候需要一些应试技巧
  5. 接收机
    1. 核心参数——灵敏度
      1. 噪声系数——过高竞争力不够，过低容易做不了
      2. 相位噪声
      3. 失真
        1. 非线性
        2. 线性
    2. 参考值——外部只有白噪声
    3. 各种干扰——怎么测，用什么指标去表征
      1. 选择性
        1. 邻道干扰——会导致降敏——具体表征是误码率误帧率——滤波器
      2. 本振的相位噪声的干扰，本振的相位噪声混频进入信号频带内——相位噪声需要足够低
      3. 组合频率进入信号率内——非线性——IP3足够高
        1. 前级增益越高，输入IP3越低，这就导致一种矛盾像是噪声抑制前级放大器越大越好，这样反而容易导致交调失真——LNA增益不能过高
      4. 平坦度，每一部分失真叠加起来
        1. 这一指标主要对以前3G很重要，对现在的4g来说要求没那么高，因为OFDM
        2. 滤波器带内本身就有纹波，滤波器窄的话，平坦度就很低，宽的话选择性就不好
        3. 有时候测试其他指标都没问题，失真严重就有可能是这个原因
      5. 正交性
      6. 时钟，现在都是网络时钟就很难存在这个问题
        1. AD采样出现的时钟抖动，和相噪有关系
        2. 眼图可以表征
        3. 解决方法就是高Q的晶振
      7. 版图设计有关

entry.title: 微波毫米波工程设计2
entry.content:
1. 信道分析

    1. 对于一个微波工程师，如果要设计通信相关的微波系统，就要对信道有一个比较深刻的理解
    2. 有线和无线的对比——什么情况下有线更有优势，什么情况下更适合无线——大趋势还是往无线上走有
    3. 多径信道——信道的叠加本质就是电场的叠加/空间特性
      1. 信道矩阵——一般只考虑幅度不考虑相位，条件数
    4. MIMO
    5. 多用户MIMO
    6. 分布式网络——cell-free

  2. 传输线

    1. 匹配的问题——多次反射来解释
      1. 传输线的多径问题（多次反射）带来的相位差，导致的信号的失真，所以需要匹配来消除反射，即消除多径效应线性电路
    2. 电报方程的简谐模式只适用于线性电路（没有其他频率产生）非线性传输线的分析还得回归最初的电报方程
    3. 为什么要以反射系数为核心研究？
      1. 反射系数的变化规律比其他的要简单，幅度不变，相位线性变化
      2. 但问题是对于复杂电路使用起来不够直观
      3. 输入阻抗的变化要复杂得多，但使用起来直观
    4. 为什么要研究驻波比？
      1. 驻波比可以清晰地反映反射系数的大小
      2. 对于某些器件的击穿电除了直流电压还要加上最大的微波电压
      3. 实际指标要求这个指标是可以量化的
    5. 传输线的复杂是一体两面的，复杂在某种意义上意味着应用的范围更广，灵活度也更高
    6. 传输线的学习不是为了记住那些概念
    7. 对于仿真软件
      1. 仿真软件现在还没有深入电路拓扑，还得人去拉线和定义
      2. 但未来设计师的价值还有多少自己还是悲观的
      3. 自己写EDA软件需要/没有条件去用EDA软件，仅仅只有几分钟的时间去决定电路的可行性问题（对于系统工程师这个技能很重要）很短时间推出大概的样子，抢订单
      4. 理论极限一定要建立概念——这样自己和甲方争论时也能言之有物，有理有据
      5. 建立估算能力对证明自己的能力很重要，所以也要重新统计所有参数，参数的大致区间也是自己的宝贵财富和经验
    8. 传输线——字面意义上的传输能量
      1. 行波状态，对驻波比的要求就是想近似行波状态
        1. 没有反射，确定性幅度不变，相位线性变化，输入阻抗纯电阻，驻波比为1
      2. 终端开路比终端短路在工程上容易实现
      3. 终端开路近似于电容处理，终端短路近似电感处理
      4. 三大求解方法的意义是为了估算，人不能成为EDA仿真软件的奴隶
    9. 同轴线
      1. 柔性电缆——半刚电缆有限弧度的折弯，外导体容易破裂，形状容易改变
      2. 半柔性电缆——兼顾半刚电缆的刚性——自己之前工作时也有这样的体会，刚性电缆拆解和理线的难度要低得多
    10. 同轴线和微带线之间的互联问题
      1. Z0一致
      2. 截面EH一致，一致度越高，连接越好，内导体放在微带线上就是EH近似相等
      3. 不能偏高，偏左，偏右，更不能偏低，那样子装配都成问题
    11. 器件引脚和微带线的互联——渐变设计

  3. 微波散射参数

    1. 反射系数的扩展是散射系数，前者是一维，后者是多维
    2. 归一化是便于电脑处理，要理解EDA的处理逻辑，才能更好理解EDA软件的不足点和自己可以提高的点
    3. 微波有些概念是相对的，比如入射波反射波不同情况下这两者都有可能
    4. S12S21互易网络默认相等下很容易得到两个解，但是实际上解唯一，会产生相位模糊——180°，但可以用于校准，校准本质上在移动参考面，仪器本质上是在测整个网络的散射参数、

  4. 仪器使用注意事项

    1. 接直流一定要慎重在慎重
    2. 电缆要轻拿轻放，尤其是毫米波电缆
    3. 每个口的最大承受功率是有限的，要避免以为没有大功率，实际上有大功率，比如出现大攻防设计的自激问题，会直接产生饱和功率

entry.title: 天线原理与设计2
entry.content:
1. friis传输方程和雷达方程

    1. 建立一个新理解，雷达方程本质上是friis传输方程的拓展
      1. 雷达的发射接收不一定在一个位置，雷达一去一回损耗更大
    2. 接收端的有效面积的拓展就是雷达反射截面积
      1. RCS-radar cross section
    3. 频率高，绕射能力差，路径损耗大，尤其是对于毫米波通信
      1. 从公式出发，功率密度与频率无关
      2. 本质上是因为接收天线在更高频率下的有效接收面积更小

  2. 点电荷的辐射场

    1. 静止电荷只有静电场，场强与场源点距离的平方成反比；
    2. 均速运动电荷（相当于恒定电流）既有静电场，又有恒流磁场，场强与场源点距离的平方成反比
    3. 静电场和恒流磁场都没有能量的空间流动，都不是辐射场
    4. 一个惯性系里的均速运动电荷，在另个以同样速度的惯性系里是静止电荷，反之亦然。既然如此，到底有没有磁场
    5. 电场和磁场都是统一的电磁张量的分量不同惯性系之间变换，磁场是相对论效应
    6. 点电荷的方向性引出一个很重要的概念，为什么不存在各向均匀辐射天线
      1. 点电荷的方向性
      2. 不同方向上不同位置的辐射源叠加的相位差不同
      3. 天线的辐射场就是点电荷辐射场的积分

  3. 偶极子天线的定义——细短天线-4.1-4.6

    1. 细—电流近似沿着z轴走
    2. 短—电流相位近似不变

  4. 近区和远区，辐射场和感应场

    1. 近区/感应场
      1. 近区既有感应场，又有辐射场；感应场大于辐射场；
      2. 近区的辐射场大于远区的辐射场。
      3. 近区场瞬时电场与偶极子的静态电场类似，因此近区场又称似稳场
      4. 近区场的电场与磁场的相位正交，是储能，平均坡印亭矢量为零，不能辐射，储能对应电抗，近区场又称感应场
      5. 感应场随距离的衰减快于辐射场
    2. 远区/辐射场
      1. 远区辐射场大于感应场，感应场极小，可以忽略
      2. 辐射场是球面波辐射场是TEM波，辐射电场、磁场与辐射方向（坡印亭矢量方向）符合右手法则。
      3. 电场与磁场同相。平均坡印亭矢量大于零，方向朝向外径向
      4. 场强与场源点距离的成反比，与电流幅度、电偶极子长度、频率成正比，与波长成反比
      5. 辐射场具有方向性，不同的空间方向辐射强度不一样辐射功率（功率与场强平方关系）
      6. 辐射电阻（功率除以电流平方）
    3. 另外注意
      1. 另一种分类方法
        1. 感应近区
        2. 辐射近区
          1. 远区-近似条件最大相位偏移pi/2注意：测超低旁瓣的时候远区距离会有影响

  5. 双偶极子天线辐射-6.2

    1. 分析注意点
      1. 两个天线的辐射场的叠加
      2. 量纲——检查错误
      3. 坐标系要统一
      4. 坐标变换-空间角和平面角要区分开
      5. 远场近似
      6. 相位中心
    2. total pattern—阵因子乘以单元的方向图——阵列天线的分析基础
      1. 决定天线方向性的因子
        1. 间距
        2. 馈角
        3. 空间角
      2. 为什么初始相位会影响方向图—理论分析

  6. 电小天线都是呈现电感特性——电能大于磁能

entry.title: 科技英语论文写作1
entry.content:
1. 论文结构

    1. 沙漏结构
      1. 宽口进——进去的大方向要宽
      2. 中间窄口——切入的小方向点要窄
      3. 宽口出——discussion和conclusion要往宽方向走
    2. 核心难点
      1. 逻辑

      1. abstract和introduction是核心难点，最好最后写——这是需要最能吸引人眼球的东西，具体句式和词语需要积累
      2. 中间两块是核心方法论

entry.title: CST从零开始2-S参数算例
entry.content:
1. 结构
    1. 创建介质柱
      1. shift-tab 开始点的位置
      2. tab 改参数
      3. 圆柱设置完了要esc，不然容易变成内外嵌套
      4. 要选择好材料和名称——体系才能保持完整
      5. ctrl+w ——框架模式
      6. pick功能很强大，不仅可以选点，还可以选选过点之间的中点
      7. 局部坐标系WCS很强大，要灵活运用好坐标系才能帮助自己的设计
    2. 创建介质中的内导体
      1. PEC是理想导体
      2. 图形的交叠——介质材料可以和理想导体重叠
        1. 理想导体在CST设置中优先级是最高的
        2. 两种不同的介质一定不能相互重叠，两种不同的导体也不能相互重叠
        3. 通过两种材料不相交可以大大降低模型的总体复杂度
    3. CST的view功能也非常强大和HFSS那个简陋的建模完全不是一回事
    4. CST-S参数设置准备——瞬态仿真就是时域仿真
      1. 定义端口
      2. 定义边界条件和对称面（怎么在原有基础上去做裁剪自己这方面能力还不够）
        1. 一般都设置为电边界
        2. 利用好对称可以节约计算资源和时间
        3. 对称面为理想磁壁——磁场无切向分量
      3. 查看网格
      4. 开始仿真
      5. 分析端口模式
      6. 分析S参量
        1. CST的主要参数都在导航树和上面导航栏里面可以直接搞出来
      7. 自适应网格加密
      8. 分析各频率的电磁场
    5. 参数化模型和自动优化结构
      1. 要充分利用好history list，有些操作必须前面的操作完全结束后才能开始进一步的操作
      2. 更改参数经常会引起结构拓扑关系的改变，从而导致结构更新改变
      3. 仿真器的精度主要取决于结构的离散化，可以通过加密网格来提高精度
      4. 截断误差定为万分之一，即accuracy为-40dB
    6. 还是得看英文指导，不要想着偷懒看中文，中文的指导过时离谱了。
    7. 很多老的指导功能其实都集成在新的模块里面，重新去找其实挺好笑的
  2. 注意CST操作界面的引导，不同部件的仿真模式是不同的，没找到仿真算法的选择在那儿，明天加以解决
  3. CST一定要记忆快捷键，自己一个个找太麻烦！！！
  4. CST软件确实很强大，一定要掌握它的微波方向的使用，会对之后的设计有很大帮助。

entry.title: 数字信号处理6-IIR
entry.content:
1. IIR infinite impulse response/FIR finite impulse response对比

    https://blog.csdn.net/qq_36024066/article/details/89508507这篇博客讲的比较详细具体——低通滤波器可以延伸设计其他三种滤波器

    FIR：有限脉冲响应滤波器。有限说明其脉冲响应是有限的。与IIR相比，FIR具有线性相位、容易设计的优点。这也就说明，IIR滤波器具有相位不线性，不容易设计的缺点。而另一方面，FIR却拥有IIR所不具有的缺点，那就是设计同样参数的滤波器，FIR比IIR需要更多的参数。这也就说明，要增加DSP的计算量。DSP需要更多的计算时间，对DSP的实时性有影响。

    FIR设计理念：就是要设计一个数字滤波器去逼近一个理想的低通滤波器。

    IIR设计理念：根据所要设计滤波器的参数去确定一个模拟滤波器的传输函数，然后再根据这个传输函数，通过双线性变换、或脉冲响应不变法来进行数字滤波器的设计。

  2. 系统响应——本质上是零极点设计，即分为ak和bk系数的确定问题

    1. 零点设计/极点设计最开始分开的
    2. 定理：级联系统可以随意改变级联顺序，不影响整体的传递方程

  3. 直接一/二型

    1. 可以看出来输入输出的差分方程以及输入输出的零极点关系
    2. 二型主要共用延迟器，降低寄存器的数量

  4. 级联型

    1. 直接型的缺点
      1. 系数不一定能准确表达出来
      2. 低阶的级联比一般n阶系统好
      3. 阶数越高，需要的位数越高，价格也就越高
      4. 系统误差对极点位置更敏感
    2. 结构类似于六阶系统是3个二阶直接型级联的结构

  5. 并联型

    1. 结构是一阶和二阶IIR系统并联可能还有Np个简单幅度加权的延迟通道
    2. 和级联的区别在于
      1. 级联是低阶零极点系统
      2. 并联是极点和residues
    3. 优点：
      1. 滤波器设计是参数自动以并行形式产生

  6. 倒置定理——信号流图

    1. 传递方程保持不变

entry.title: 现代数字信号处理2-统计信号处理
entry.content:
1. 信号处理最经典模型——X(数据)=A(实际信号)+N(噪声建模)
    1. 数据是上帝
  2. 信号建模没什么神丹妙药，关键就是建立好一套标准
    1. 均值、方差建立好一套标准
    2. 建立误差方程——通过定义某种距离来衡量信号的先验损失
    3. 建模时会屈从于能力的不足
  3. MMSE——最小化均方误差（mean square error）
    1. 学会一加一减拆分
    2. MSE可以分成两部分一部分是方差一部分是偏差
    3. 换个角度理解可以理解为随机误差和系统误差，估计很多时候就是在bias和variance之间做trade-off
    4. 偏差可以校准，方差必须尽可能小，结合手表去理解。
  4. 无偏估计——平均值=估计的参数
    1. 一定要搞清楚什么是未知量什么是确定量
    2. 样本均值会降低自由度
  5. 估计的要求
    1. uniformly——对于任意数据都很高，不会有片面性
    2. UMV——一致最小方差
    3. 最小均方估计=E(Y|X)
  6. 补充概念
    1. 条件期望——在多种随机因素下，通过各个击破的方法即条件一部分，解决一部分
      1. 赋予某些随机变量暂时的确定性实现对多个随机变量的分析
      2. 条件期望再期望=无条件期望
    2. 条件方差——在原先方差的计算式里面每一处期望都加上条件
      1. 条件方差=条件方差的期望+条件期望的方差
      2. 所谓千变万化，只是那十几个招式的各种排列组合
    3. 充分统计量——sufficient statistics
      1. 最小化均方差还需要考虑怎么尽可能包含所有θ的信息
      2. 估计和估计，统计和统计出现差异的本质原因在于关于θ的相关信息的捕获上有差异
      3. 定义：RA fisher充分估计
  7. 优化过程
    1. θ1无偏估计
    2. θ2充分统计
    3. θ3=E(θ1|θ2)即更好的估计
      1. 均值=θ
      2. 方差小于θ1的方差
    4. θ3的选取目标只依赖于采样数据，不依赖于未知参数的个数
    5. 对于这样的优化过程，是否存在一个估计总体约束的下界
  8. 补充
    1. 在学习和后来的研究中，一定要注意有一些隐含的条件和假设，你默认的却没有表明出来

entry.title: 数字信号处理4-循环卷积
entry.content:
circular convolution

  1. 循环卷积用周期格式和线性卷积来表示

  2. 循环卷积用线性卷积实现

    1. 按照定义实现
    2. 根据线性的性质交换次序优化

  3. 循环卷积的本质：线性卷积+混叠

    1. 混叠——延迟N重复叠加
    2. N决定了混叠程度的大小
    3. N——脉冲串之间的间距

  4. 选取合适的N可以从循环卷积恢复成线性卷积，前者的脉冲串间距要大于后者

    1. 根据这一原理用零填充（padding with zero）方法实现循环卷积到线性卷积
    2. 循环卷积的实现难度一般要比线性卷积更难以实现，所以尽可能变成线性卷积

  5. 块卷积法处理信号，把滤波信号分成长度为L的段，每段信号就可以与有限长脉冲响应进行卷积，并用一种适当的方法把滤波后的信号衔接在一起

    1. 适当的方法
      1. 重叠相加法——滤波后的序列段形成滤波后输出序列
      2. 重叠保留法——输入序列有重叠，每个接续的输入序列包含一部分新点，也包含先前序列保留下的一部分店
      3. 不能脑子还停留在过去的思维模式，信号处理不是单纯的恢复信号

entry.title: 数字信号处理3-DFT
entry.content:
1. DFS—离散傅里叶序列，是一个序列，而不是一个连续变量的函数，相应于对信号的傅里叶变换进行频率的等间隔取样的样本。
  2. 有限长序列的处理方式是周期化变成周期序列，然后根据离散傅里叶级数解决问题
  3. DFT和DFS要对应学习和理解，DFT是有限长序列的周期等价系数的傅里叶变换，是DFS一个周期的提取
  4. DFT相当于z变换在单位圆上的采样
  5. DFS的表示方法，与DTFT有所变化要对比着学习
  6. DFS特性
    1. shifting
      1. 周期序列的傅里叶变换，要理解circular shift，要与之前的linear shift区分开来，要结合图像理解。
    2. symmetry——对偶性质
      1. 在一个周期里面的对称0~N-1
    3. 卷积（注意是circular卷积）
      1. 两个圆筒旋转卷积，一个圆筒翻转加在另一个圆筒上，两个圆筒叠在一起，卷积的过程就是圆筒转动时相互的序列值相乘最后相加的过程就相当于与二维化

entry.title: ADS射频电路仿真学习笔记4-微带天线仿真

  2. ads这块的学习主要着力于匹配电路的设计，momentum仿真主要用于场仿真，可以去仿真匹配与天线耦合，而原理图则是路仿真。
  3. 微带天线的阻抗一般都是100~200Ω，需要接一段阻抗匹配电路，最后连上输入点。一般工作在谐振点，要对S参数有针对性的优化。
  4. 微带天线优点
    1. 剖面薄，体积小，重量轻
    2. 平面结构，共形设计
    3. 馈电网络可以和天线集成在一起
    4. 能和有源器件以及电源集成在一起
    5. 便于实现圆极化，双频带和双极化
  5. 微带天线缺点
    1. 频带窄
    2. 导体和介质损耗大，表面波
    3. 功率容量小
    4. 受基片材料影响大
  6. 天线设计对理论要求很高，不能和电路那样单纯只会应用和强行仿真上去，要多动动脑子和深入理论推导，不然很难找到设计方法和优化的方向，哪怕只是微带天线这种最简单的天线。
  7. 微带天线设计方法
    1. 传输模法—把矩形块等效为辐射阻抗加载的一段很宽的微带线，近似并且需要实验调整
    2. 谐振模法—把微带天线看成有碰壁的封闭腔体
  8. 直接在layout里面仿真，按照步骤走，不要忘了设置端口（插入pin），实质上就是计算一些常见规整的阻抗，linecale计算线宽和线长或者反过来计算阻抗和相位，是个很重要的工具，阻抗匹配可以用tools-Smithchart，也可以设定S11目标进行优化来权衡线长的设计（便于工业化生产，往往线宽是固定的）
  9. 馈线不宜过长，因为微带天线本质也是一个微带线，过长导致自身也会变成一个天线，会对主天线的方向图造成干扰
  10. 可以把天线的参数导出到原理图上去进行仿真设计和优化

    4. 注意单位的问题，次数过高可以用类似e7e8代替。
    5. 仿真结果输出时注意格式问题。
    6. 小心大小写和中文格式下的标点符号，容易出现莫名其妙的报错。
  2. 如何设置扫描参数的问题
  3. 直流仿真—非线性参数的初步估算（频率为零的信号，当成普通理想低频电路看待）
    1. 要结合模拟电路去分析，确定工作点和偏置电路。
    2. 创建子电路，对于复杂电路如何规范化和模块化设计很重要，设置可以改变的参数便于上级电路使用。
  4. 交流仿真—小信号传输参数的近似线性变换分析
    1. 线性预算电路仿真—在交流仿真模块里
    2. 测噪声的时候可以分析噪声的分布和来源
    3. 相位特性—输入和输出的相位关系
  5. S参数仿真—主要针对无源器件
    1. 相位延时—群延时这二者用S参数仿真，测量端口间信号传输时间。
    2. 要真正理解史密斯圆图，终端阻抗可以在不同频率下显示不同的值。
    3. 匹配电路是核心和重中之重，最近学的主要是一般LC仿真，带宽都没有很高。掌握好自带的Smithchart模块，先匹配一边再去匹配另一边
    4. 联合参数优化-optimization，设置goal，注意步进和收敛区域，会影响最后数据的可信性，针对的还是主要是匹配电路——这不是废话吗，一般不就只能改匹配电路吗。
    5. 优化方向比如噪声系数仿真也是一样
  6. HB仿真—非线性电路的稳态响应
    1. 噪声/非线性特性（交调失真）/输入输出的频谱成分
    2. [1]是指几次谐波的意思，ts函数可以把频域信号变成是与信号
    3. 压缩功率输出—XdB仿真器法和谐波平衡法看输入输出的变化关系——PA等有源器件的非线性
    4. TOI（三阶交调分量）主要影响的是邻近信道之间的干扰
    5. 注意上边带和下边带的交调分量，可以直接用公式ip3_out确定大致的范围，再用RF功率扫描确定具体的值
  7. 电路包络仿真（envelop）—非线性电路的非稳态响应
    1. 主要针对各种复杂的调制波形和随时间变化的电路设计很有用，还有分析信道也很有用
    2. 注意步长和仿真总时程对仿真的影响，对仿真起止时间、时间间隔、基准频率。谐波次数和参数扫描要认真选择。
    3. 包络仿真器的stop设置要满足整个脉冲宽度，包括上升、下降时间和延迟。
    4. 要真正理解参数的含义，不能只停留在简单代公式上

entry.title: ADS射频电路仿真学习笔记1-常用仿真器
entry.content:
• 常见仿真器

    • 直流仿真

      • 电路拓扑检查

      • 直流工作点扫描和分析、功耗计算和温度扫描

    • 交流仿真——小信号传输(线性设计)

      • 设计对象

        • 无源电路和小信号有源电路（低噪声放大器）

      • 测试对象

        • 电压增益、电流增益、线性噪声电压、线性噪声电流

    • S参数仿真——非线性网络

  • 测量参数

    • S11 S22——输入输出驻波特性

      • S21——电路的幅频特性和相频特性和群时延

    • S12——隔离性能

      • 群延时

    • 线性噪声

      • 频率改变对小信号的影响

    • 谐波（HB）平衡仿真——信号频域特性——非线性网络——小信号分析

      • 设计对象

        • 射频放大器、混频器、振荡器、设计大规模RFIC或RF/IF子系统——存在大量谐波和交调成分

      • 适用范围

        • 调制的周期信号可以用几个简单的单载波及其谐波来表示/傅里叶级数展开式很简单

        • 不具备简单周期信号特点的CDMA信号就不适用（复杂的需要采用包络仿真）

      • 原理

        • 一般网络由线性子网络和非线性子网络组成

          • 线性子网络——频率代数特性

          • 非线性子网络——时域的非线性方程

        • 平衡时

          • 经傅里叶变换的时域的线性子网络的端口电压和电流应该满足非线性子网络的端口电压和电流

          • 反之亦然

        • 设定一个最大的谐波数，建立一个线性子网络电压/电流和非线性子网络电压/电流的误差函数

          • 通过迭代，实现稳态的线性子网络和非线性子网络的谐波平衡

      • 测试对象（非线性指标）

        • 噪声系数（噪声）、饱和电平、三阶交调（非线性指标）、本振泄露、镜像抑制、中频抑制、组合干扰（混频器和链路分析用）

    • 大信号S参数仿真——大信号分析

      • 设计对象——功放

      • 谐波平衡仿真的一种

    • 增益压缩仿真（XDB）——增益压缩点的寻找（谐波仿真也可以测dB压缩点）

    • 电路包络仿真——数模混合仿真和数字微波系统、复杂调制波形的仿真、随时间变化的电路（PLL/AGC/调制器/VCO）

      • 原理（谐波平衡法的延伸和拓展）

        • 高频调制信号分解为时域和频域进行处理

          • 时域-相对低频的调制信息直接采样

          • 高频-谐波平衡的方法在频域处理

      • 研究对象

        • 调制解调以及混合调制信号的电路和系统
        • 信道的失真仿真

    • 瞬态仿真

      • 直接在时域对电流电压列节点方程，采用一刀切的方式，对所有模拟数字电路进行仿真

      • 高频信号很难采用SPICE处理，需要更高的CPU

  • 微波射频电路设计的ADS仿真器

    • 最常用——S参数仿真、电路包络仿真、谐波平衡仿真

    • 滤波器

      • S参数

    • 混频器

      • DC——工作点状态

      • AC——增益、噪声电压、噪声电流

      • 谐波平衡——IP3、IF

      • transient——瞬态响应

      • envelope——包络仿真

    • 功放

      • S参数仿真

      • 谐波平衡——各种谐波和交调

      • LSSP——大信号S参数

      • XDB——P-1

      • envelop——包络特性

    • 接收机

      • AC

      • 谐波平衡仿真——谐波和交调

      • 包络——复杂波形

    • 振荡器

      • DC——节点电压、电流

      • 谐波仿真——谐波和交调

      • 包络仿真

    • 锁相环

      • 包络——相位噪声

entry.title: 数字信号处理1-DTFT
entry.content:
1. 离散时间信号系统

    1. 采样，把采样sampling当成滤波器看待是一个很有意思的思路，理解采样定理必须和混叠aliasing相结合起来，混叠也是可以变废为宝的，导师之前提到过一个类似的思路，将之前的必须消除的表面波用作处理简单的交互。
    2. 理解LSI线性时不变系统，这是最基本也最常用的模型，复杂的模型也是在这基础上修改过的。
    3. 稳定性和因果性：这是信号系统最核心的两大性质。稳定就是输入有限输出必然有限，因果就是系统无法预见未来。实用中一般采用稳定系统，因果和非因果系统都有可以实际应用。因果稳定也可以作为限制条件来确定系数，处理最基本的问题即线性常系数微分方程
    4. 自己之前优点畏惧频率响应这个词，本质是就是幅度和相位，没有什么复杂的东西，抓性质和趋势，具体细节用matlab描绘，系统的频率响应即H(jw)就是w的函数，2π周期性也要注意

  2. 离散时间傅里叶变换

    1. 理解着整个过程，自己的理解有的地方不到位，
    2. 数字滤波器连续信号采样变成采样信号频谱，通过CD变成离散信号序列，经过Hd(jw)变成y(n)，再通过DC周期复制，再经过低通滤波器过滤出y(t)信号，不要和通信系统混淆。
    3. DTFT不是对所有序列均存在，都能收敛——引入z变换和确定收敛域
